macro.para:
This macro expands to a binary containing a binary tree which contains the elements of seq as the second element and the depth of that tree as the first element. This is accomplished by pairing elements in seq according to the following pattern: pairing two adjacent elements, a and b, results in (, (a), (b)). This pairing is applied to the entire to produce a new of pairs. This is illustrated by the following pseudo-code:
(a)(b)(c)(d) => (, (a), (b))(, (c), (d))
If the number of elements in the is odd, the last element will be paired with nothing. For example,
(a)(b)(c) => (, (a), (b))(, (c),)
The pairing process of the is repeatedly applied to the resulting until a one-element is produced. The number of times that the pairing process is repeated is the depth of the resulting binary tree.
(a)(b) => (, (a), (b))
(a)(b)(c)(d) => (, (a), (b))(, (c), (d)) => (, (1, (a), (b)), (, (c), (d)))
(a)(b)(c)(d)(e)(f)(g)(h) => (, (a), (b))(, (c), (d))(, (e), (f))(, (g), (h)) => (, (, (a), (b)), (, (c), (d)))(1, (, (e), (f)), (, (g), (h))) => (, (, (, (a), (b)), (, (c), (d))), (, (, (e), (f)), (, (g), (h))))
In the first pseudo-code transformation above, the depth is 1, in the second, the depth is 2, and in the third, the depth is is 3. The algorithm yields both the depth and resulting binary tree:
((a)(b)) // (1, (, (a), (b)))
((a)(b)(c)(d)) // (2, (, (, (a), (b)), (, (c), (d))))
((a)(b)(c)(d)(e)(f)(g)(h)) // (3, (, (, (, (a), (b)), (, (c), (d))), (, (, (e), (f)), (, (g), (h)))))
